support.p: Gwynedd Archaeological Trust Regional Historic Environment Record: 3033
support.material: Relatively local (1.5km to NW), coarse-grained pebbly sandstone

layoutDesc.layout: The stone is inscribed with a Roman-letter inscription in the centre of its largest smooth face just beneath a diagonal fault line. The inscription is in one line reading vertically downwards. The stone is also inscribed with an ogham inscription in one line on the right-hand edge of the face inscribed with Roman letters. The ogham inscription reads vertically upwards. Both inscriptions are incised (Edwards 2013, 163).

handDesc.handNote: The characters in the Roman-letter inscription are standard capitals. MA are ligatured, the strokes are widely spaced and touch the line; the horizontal of the L slopes downwards below the line and the second smaller I is tucked above; S is larger; final I is horizontal (Tedeschi 2005, 198). Regarding the ogham inscription, the Welsh Corpus notes that the position of the oghams, on the right angle of [the Roman-letter inscribed face] rather than on the left, is less usual, but their closeness to the roman-letter inscription was presumably to indicate that one was the translation of the other (Edwards 2013, 165).

origin.origPlace: Llanfaelog,Anglesey (Ynys Môn) 53.221267, -4.497758 National Grid Reference: SH 3334 7227

history.provenance: The stone was first recorded by Skinner in 1802 at Penseri Farm (Penseri Bach, Penseiri Bach) where it was reused as a window lintel in a barn, though it was reported to have been taken from a field nearby. The stone was reported lost for a time but rediscovered in exactly the space spot in 1945. The stone was moved to its current location in 2001 when the barn was demolished. The ogham was first noticed here by Nancy Edwards in August 2007 (Edwards 2013, 162).
Set in the ground in an outbuilding north of the farmhouse at Trecastell (Edwards 2013, 162).

app.note: The fragmentary ogham inscription has been reconstructed with the assumption that it corresponds to the roman-letter inscription, which is supported by the space available between the surviving characters. Regarding the final U, Sims-Williams notes that since only three strokes are evident, 'it should be read, as expected in Irish, as MA[ILI]SU (nominative)' (Edwards 2013, 164-5).

item.p: The roman-letter inscription, like the ogham, commemorates a person named Mailisi and consists solely of this name. Sims-Williams (Edwards 2013, 165) notes that in theory, MAILISI could be formed from Welsh... [but] the occurrence of ogham on the stone and the fact that the other name from Llanfaelog (CVNOGVSI on Llanfaelog 1 (AN12)) is Irish make it much more likely that MAILISI is Irish, presumably with the element mael 'bald/tonsured one', common in ecclesiastical names... It seems that MAILISI must be a brutal Latinization of Máel Ísu ('bald one of Jesus'), with the ubiquitous Latin 'epigraphic -I' genitive having been added inappropriately to an Irish name, as also in Llanfaelog 1 and elsewhere in Britain.

Sims-Williams (Edwards 2013, 165) also commented that 'if there is a connection between MAILISI and the name Llanfaelog, one must assume that the Irish name Máel Ísu was assimilated to the well-known Welsh name Maelog; the latter may have been employed here as a hypocoristic form of Máel Ísu.
